prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Factors militating against transfer—Factors opposing transfer generally

para.paratext: Most of the factors set forth in § 5:13 can, by their absence, constitute factors militating against transfer. Certainly the absence of any of the three factors required by the statute will prevent transfer.[1] There are, however, certain factors that may have little impact on transfer if they are present, yet have great influence upon the Panel's decision if not present. These factors are discussed in this section.

Even where the factors may be present, the Panel occasionally denies transfer for the simple reason that there doesn't seem to be a strong enough showing that transfer would be worth the effort. In some recent cases the Panel essentially just states that there is not a strong enough showing that transfer would accomplish the purposes of transfer.[2] Similarly, although there may be sufficient commonality of fact issues to allow transfer, that Panel may determine that there is absence of sufficient number of complex factual issues to justify transfer.[3] This factor has become a frequently announced reason for denying transfer.

The absence of factors favoring transfer inherently militates against transfer. Probably the best example of this is the number of actions. Every other factor that militates against transfer is only more likely to prevent it where the number of actions affected is small. The absence of overlapping class actions, even in a docket comprising 10 cases in five different districts has been noted as a reason to deny transfer.[4] The Panel does make an effort to assess what is actually going to happen in the cases, if transferred. Even if the case presents common issues that would allow the Panel to order transfer, it will attempt to guage the balance between common issues and those unique to individual actions.[5] Where it concludes that the common issues are not sufficiently complex compared with the noncommon issues, it may deny transfer.[6]

A broad factor that is rarely discussed by the Panel, but undoubtedly weighs into the analysis of whether to order transfer, is the general track record in similar cases—if the parties can typically get a similar cases resolved efficiently without the extraordicnary step of nationwide centralization, the Panel should not entertain 1407 centralization. This reflex may be reflected in a particular docket, where similar cases involving some of the same parties have clearly been able to resolve litigation without centralization.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

The Panel's consideration of the pendency of motions in the transferor court is discussed in § 5:40. See, e.g., In re Arrivalstar S.A. Fleet Management Systems Patent Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (patentholder had brought nearly 100 actions in seven years; managed without centralization, and not one even proceeding to claim construction).
See, e.g., In re Orthalliance, Inc., Contract Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Solaia Technology LLC Patent & Antitrust Litigation, 346 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2004).

In re: LVNV Funding, LLC, Time-Barred Proof of Claim Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) Litigation, 96 F. Supp. 3d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: LVNV Funding, LLC, Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) Litigation, 96 F. Supp. 3d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: Nutek Baby Wipes Products Liability Litigation, 96 F. Supp. 3d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: Impulse Monitoring, Inc., Humana Intraoperative Monitoring Services Claims and Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) Litigation, 84 F. Supp. 3d 1376 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: Convergent Outsourcing, Inc., Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) Litigation, 84 F. Supp. 3d 1369 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: Narconon Drug Rehabilitation Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 84 F. Supp. 3d 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: Minute Maid Pomegranate Blueberry Flavored Juice Blend Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 84 F. Supp. 3d 1365 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015) (simple and relatively straightforward docket); In re: Hangtime, Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 52 F. Supp. 3d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (cases not particularly complex, as well as being few in number); In re Mortgage Industry Foreclosure Litigation, 996 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2014) (issues straight-forward, not sufficiently complex); In re Goodman Mfg. Co., L.P., HVAC Products Liability Litigation, 987 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Kashi Company Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 959 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Bally Total Fitness Holding Corp. Lifetime Membership Agreement Contract Litigation, 883 F. Supp. 2d 1343 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Crest Sensitivity Treatment & Protection Toothpaste Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Northeast Contaminated Beef Products Liability Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Plasma Arc Technologies Inc., Due Diligence Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1338 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Highway Accident in Fulton County, Ohio, on August 2, 2009, 829 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Trilegiant Membership Program Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 828 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Ronald Beecher Estate Litigation, 816 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Hercules Offshore, Inc., Securities and Derivative Litigation, 816 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Webloyalty.com, Inc., Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 768 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Americredit Deficiency Balance Collection Litigation, 732 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2010); In re Public Records Collection Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) Litigation, 641 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Glaceau Vitaminwater Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 641 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re S.C. Johnson & Son, Inc., Greenlist Label Marketing & Sales Practices Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1317 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Dorel Juvenile Group, Inc., Stroller (MODEL 834) Products Liability Litigation, 598 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re U.S.A. Exterminators, Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Litigation, 588 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Cardinal Health, Inc., Contract Litigation, 588 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Title Ins. Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) & Antitrust Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (noting that actions involved different regulatory schemes in each state involved in litigation).

In re Tyson Foods, Inc., Meat Processing Facilities Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2008). See also In re Arizona Beverage Co. Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 609 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (three single-state class actions did not present overlap).

In re Table Saw Products Liability Litigation, 641 F. Supp. 2d 1384 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (common issues “overshadowed by non-common ones”); In re Victoria's Secret Undergarments/Intimate Apparel Products Liability Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1349 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Tyson Foods, Inc., Meat Processing Facilities Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (noting that discovery likely to be specific to each plant of defendant).

See, e.g., In re S.C. Johnson & Son, Inc., Greenlist Label Marketing & Sales Practices Litigation, 626 F. Supp. 2d 1317 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (common issue in two actions “relatively uncomplicated”); In re Dorel Juvenile Group, Inc., Stroller (MODEL 834) Products Liability Litigation, 598 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (transfer denied where only two actions were pending and common issues viewed not sufficiently complex).
